baseline completion: ill inmates are housed in Miami before trial. MIAMI, Florida (CNN) -- The ninth floor of the Miami-Dade pretrial detention facility is dubbed the "forgotten floor." Here, inmates with the most severe mental illnesses are incarcerated until they're ready to appear in court. Most often, they face drug charges or charges of assaulting an officer --charges that Judge Steven Leifman says are usually "avoidable felonies." He says the arrests often result from confrontations with police. Mentally ill people often won't do what they're told when police arrive on the scene -- confrontation seems to exacerbate their illness and they become more paranoid, delusional, and less likely to follow directions, according to Leifman. So, they end up on the ninth floor severely mentally disturbed, but not getting any real help because they're in jail. We toured the jail with Leifman. Tomas Medina Caracas, known popularly as "El Negro Acacio," was a member of the high command of the Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia and, according to Colombian and U.S. officials, helped manage the group's extensive cocaine trafficking network. He had been in the cross-hairs of the U.S. Justice Department since 2002. He was charged with conspiracy to import cocaine into the United States and manufacturing and distributing cocaine within Colombia to fund the FARC's 42-year insurgency against the government. U.S. officials alleged Medina Caracas managed the rebel group's sales of cocaine to international drug traffickers, who in turn smuggled it into the United States. He was also indicted in the United States along with two other FARC commanders in November 2002 on charges of conspiring to kidnap two U.S. oil workers from neighboring Venezuela in 1997 and holding one of them for nine months until a $1 million ransom was paid. Tomas Medina Caracas, known popularly as "El Negro Acacio," was a member of the high command of the Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia and, according to Colombian and U.S. officials, helped manage the group's extensive cocaine trafficking network. He had been in the cross-hairs of the U.S. Justice Department since 2002. U.S. officials alleged Medina Caracas managed the rebel group's sales of cocaine to international drug traffickers, who in turn smuggled it into the United States. prompt: (CNN) -- A virus found in healthy Australian honey bees may be playing a role in the collapse of honey bee colonies across the United States, researchers reported Thursday. Honey bees walk on a moveable comb hive at the Bee Research Laboratory, in Beltsville, Maryland. Colony collapse disorder has killed millions of bees
original watermarked completion:
in America in recent years. (AP Photo/Patrick Semansky)

Scientists say the new virus may be causing honey bees to lose their appetite.

In recent years, beekeepers have experienced unusually large losses of their honey bee colonies. The losses have been linked to a mysterious disease known as colony collapse disorder, or CCD.

Lee, a 53-year-old chief subway technician in Hong Kong, was diagnosed with liver cancer in January 2005 but doctors denied him a transplant because they feared the tumor would spread. In doing so, they ignored a request by Italy coach Roberto Donadoni to play the first round of matches midway through the month, to give his players time to gain match-fitness ahead of Euro 2008 qualifiers against France and Ukraine in early September. "I'm ready to leave the Italian Players Association. We are the principal actors, but also the people who are never listened to," Totti was quoted as saying in Italian football magazine Dieci. "This is the moment in which we must make our voice heard. We wanted to start on August 19, to have an extra week's rest at Christmas and allow the national team to come into the big matches in September better prepared. prompt: LOS ANGELES, California (CNN) -- Youssif, the 5-year-old burned Iraqi boy, rounded the corner at Universal Studios when suddenly the little boy hero met his favorite superhero. Youssif has always been a huge Spider-Man fan. Meeting him was "my favorite thing,"
original watermarked completion:
said Youssif's father, Mohamed Hamed.

It's been a long journey for Youssif who was born with severe burns to about 70 percent of his body, as well as a small hole in his heart. He had the surgeries to repair his heart, and received therapy for years for burns and burns-related neuropathy.

After a lot of time and effort and a lot of prayers, Youssif was discharged from UCLA Medical Center in May and has had a tough road to recovery. He had to relearn how to walk, use his arms and his legs. He's now about 7 months old, but he still needs to have his heart and his hands repaired and is going through a lot of therapy and physical therapy, his mom, Nadia, said.

The family has traveled to many different cities in the U.S. to meet and see their son in person. They're scheduled to go to Disney World this Saturday.

prompt: (CNN) -- A Marine convicted for his role in the death of an Iraqi civilian was sentenced Friday to a reduction in rank and will be discharged. Cpl. Trent D. Thomas was found guilty Wednesday of kidnapping and conspiracy to commit several offenses -- including murder, larceny, housebreaking, kidnapping, and
original watermarked completion:
false imprisonment -- in the June 2006 death of Mohammed Naim, an Iraqi civilian who was taken by U.S. soldiers in a helicopter from Baghdad to a military installation in Kuwait.

According to a U.S. Army investigation, the Iraq military operation began with a helicopter ride where the soldiers were told by commanders to make sure an Iraqi civilian would be released in return for an American soldier's release in Kuwait. The soldiers did as they were told, and Naim was kidnapped from a civilian convoy as it passed the base.

Thomas, 20, of New Hampshire, was tried for murder and conspiracy to commit offenses against his fellow service members and other persons and was sentenced to 15 years in prison on July 13.

He will receive a reduced rank, be dishonorably discharged and his military career
